Award.AwardTitle: Cryptic Hydrology of the McMurdo Dry Valleys: Water Track Contributions to Water and Geochemical Budgets in Taylor Valley, Antarctica
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit:
The PIs propose to quantify the hillslope water, solute, and carbon budgets for Taylor Valley in the McMurdo Dry Valleys, using water tracks to investigate near-surface geological processes and challenge the paradigm that shallow groundwater is minimal or non-exixtant. Water tracks are linear zones of high soil moisture that route shallow groundwater downslope in permafrost dominated soils. Four hypotheses will be tested: 1) water tracks are important pathways for water and solute transport; 2) water tracks transport more dissolved silica than streams in Taylor Valley indicating they are the primary site of chemical weathering for cold desert soils and bedrock; 3) water tracks that drain highland terrains are dominated by humidity-separated brines while water tracks that drain lowland terrains are dominated by marine aerosols; 4) water tracks are the sites of the highest terrestrial soil carbon concentrations and the strongest CO2 fluxes in Taylor Valley and their carbon content increases with soil age, while carbon flux decreases with age. To test these hypotheses the PIs will carry out a suite of field measurements supported by modeling and remote sensing. They will install shallow permafrost wells in water tracks that span the range of geological, climatological, and topographic conditions in Taylor Valley. Multifrequency electromagnetic induction sounding of the upper ~1 m of the permafrost will create the first comprehensive map of soil moisture in Taylor Valley, and will permit direct quantification of water track discharge across the valley. The carbon contents of water track soils will be measured and linked to global carbon dynamics.

Broader impacts:
Non-science majors at Oregon State University will be integrated into the proposed research through a new Global Environmental Change course focusing on the scientific method in Antarctica. Three undergraduate students, members of underrepresented minorities, will be entrained in the research, will contribute to all aspects of field and laboratory science, and will present results at national meetings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on understanding the origin, climate significance, and ecological effects of water tracks—the shallow meltwater channels that form each summer atop the perennially frozen ground in Antarctica. Water tracks are important because they are the main locations in which chemical weathering alters Antarctic rocks and because they dominate the storage and release of carbon from Antarctic soils. Over three field seasons, we measured shallow groundwater composition (salts, nutrients, clay content, etc.), soil and ice properties, and biological community functioning on the water tracks. As a consequence of this research, several key discoveries and outcomes have resulted:

1) This work has, for the first time, uncovered the interconnected “cryptic” hydrological system that operates in shallow subsurface soils in Antarctica. This salty groundwater system shapes Antarctic geology, hydrology, and biology, and operates at temperatures well below freezing. We have shown that water tracks crisscross Antarctic landscapes, moving salts, nutrients, and carbon and shaping patterns of weathering, biological productivity, and even melting of ancient ground ice. Science findings include:

A) Water tracks are historical parts of the Taylor Valley hydrological system and are not “new” features. However, warmer temperatures and enhanced snowfall  resulting from Antarctic climate change will likely result in the formation of new and larger water tracks.

B) Water tracks are zones of high soil carbon in the Antarctic polar desert. Yet this carbon appears to be primarily relict carbon, with only a small amount of microbial carbon that can survive in the briny environment.

C) Water tracks dominate the energy balance of the soil environment in Taylor Valley, controlling depth of thaw via changes in water track albedo and soil thermal properties. Wet soils melt deeply and may accelerate the thaw of underlying ice.

D) Water tracks range in salinity from nearly fresh to hypersaline. This means that they can remain active, shaping the Antarctic landscape even after soil temperatures fall below 0?C.

E) Water tracks have unique optical properties that mean they can be mapped using satellite spectrometers. This result paves the way to monitoring water track evolution from space.

F) Groundwater can form in water tracks through hydration of soil salts. This means that wet soil can form even in the absence of precipitation.

G) Water track flow rates are largely shaped by the underlying soil properties, meaning that ice-age or multi-million-year-old legacies in the form of variable sand/silt content in soils can shape modern landscape response to warming and melting.

H) Finally, water tracks have been shown to challenge the commonly held belief that liquid water is the key, limiting factor in MDV soil ecosystems. Water tracks have extremely high salinities, which results in reduced respiration and lower microbial populations in in water track soils compared to adjacent, off-track soils, even though water track soils can be 5-10 times wetter than the adjacent dry soils. Community genomics studies have shown that water tracks have a unique community composition that is adapted to high-salinity environments and that may occupy the unusual niche of metabolizing organic matter preserved in water track brines.

2. This project has resulted in more than ten peer-reviewed research publications that explain the geological, hydrological, geochemical, and biological functioning of the water tracks.

3. Field research on Antarctic water tracks led to development of the techniques used to explore shallow groundwater features on Mars. By understanding the flow of water and salts in the coldest, driest place on Earth, we can better understand the potential habitability of wet soils on Mars. ...
